Its main purpose is to provide financial security to workers, and the funds deposited into the FGTS are not directly accessible by the employee during their employment but can be withdrawn under specific circumstances, such as: purchasing a home; retirement; and difficult situations, which may occur with dismissal without just cause or in the event of serious illnesses. The FGTS &#8220;anniversary withdrawal&#8221; was created in 2019 and provides the option to access a fraction of these resources annually. With that, a new secured personal loan product was launched in April 2020 using the FGTS anniversary withdrawal as collateral, providing an attractive product in terms of price. This collateralized personal loan product became widely adopted and now represents over 30% of the personal non-payroll loans category, with an outstanding balance of more than US$16 billion as of December 2023, according to publicly available data published by the FGTS. Nubank launched the FGTS-backed loan in September 2023, and it represented more than 10% of our new consumer loan originations in 2024. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 73 &#160; &#160; Investment-backed Personal Loans Investment-backed loans gained popularity as digital and incumbent institutions introduced them as a new personal loan product in the context of a low SELIC rate environment in recent years. Although there are no consolidated industry figures available on the product, we estimate that it expanded sharply from 2020 until 2023 and moderated somewhat in 2024. We estimate that it may have reached close to 10% of total personal non-payroll loans in Brazil. Nubank launched this product in June 2023 and it represented less than 5% of our new consumer loan originations in 2024. Credit Card Financing and Revolving The Brazil's banking industry total credit card interest earning portfolio totaled US$25 billion on average in 2024, or 24% of the total outstanding credit card receivables, while the remaining 76% are defined as transaction balances - referring to upfront credit card purchases and Parcelado sem Juros , or &#8220;PSJ&#8221;, transactions (i.e. installment purchases that do not bear interest charges and that amount to almost half of purchase volumes, usually in up to 12 installments). During 2023, discussions among credit card industry stakeholders were held regarding a potential cap on revolving interest rates required by the government due to the relatively high level of interest rates on the product, driven primarily by the large number of PSJs in the industry and their impact on household debt levels and default rates. The CMN ( Conselho Monet&#225;rio Nacional ) limited revolving interest balances equivalent to a maximum of 100% of the customer's principal outstanding revolving loan, starting in January 2024. Nubank expanded its credit offering to consumers and small businesses through our Pix and bill financing products. Credit underwriting Incumbent banks in Latin America have traditionally focused on the most affluent segments of the population. Operating under a higher cost-to-serve model than digital banks and relying on legacy underwriting frameworks, incumbents have struggled to effectively serve customers from the less affluent segments. We believe this represents a significant opportunity to continue advancing financial inclusion in the region. Additionally, we have made considerable progress in launching products and features on our app to expand offerings to higher-income segments, and have a clear and well-defined development pipeline for the coming years, seeking to address the needs of all customer segments in Latin America. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 74 &#160; &#160; When analyzing the distribution of retail loan balances by income brackets relative to the number of households in each bracket in Brazil, we observe that retail credit remains concentrated among high-income individuals who according to our internal estimates, concentrate for close to 32% of the industry's revenue while representing less than 3% of the adult population. Brazil Retail Credit Portfolio by Consumer's Income Segment &#160; &lt;1x Minimum Wage 1&#8211;2x Minimum Wage 2&#8211;3x Minimum Wage 3&#8211;5x Minimum Wage 5&#8211;10x Minimum Wage &gt;10x Minimum Wage Monthly Income (US$)&#185; &lt;259 259 &#8211; 518 518 &#8211; 777 777 &#8211; 1,295 1,295 &#8211; 2,591 &gt;2,591 2024 average Credit Balance (US$ billion) 2 47 91 63 86 105 230 2024 average Credit Balance (% share) 7% 13% 9% 13% 15% 33% Note 1: Exchange rate: &#8203;BRL 5.39 to USD 1.00 for 2024 data; Source: BCB. Note 2: Credit Balance includes credit card balances, personal loans, payroll loans, auto loans, home mortgages, and others. The BCB reported US$69 billion outstanding credit balance with no available information on the consumer's income levels, accounting for 10% of the total credit. 1 Credit Balance includes credit card balances, personal loans, payroll loans, auto loans, home mortgages, and others. The BCB reported US$69 billion outstanding credit with not available information on customer income levels, accounting for 10% of the total credit. We use an internally developed credit engine, called NuX, leveraging proprietary and alternative data sources to effectively underwrite and monitor our credit products. Our NuX Credit Engine, supported by a dedicated team, is self-learning and benefits from increasing scale as we test, monitor and enhance our credit algorithms. We acquire, store and analyze an enormous amount of data that we use for our decision-making processes, to reduce risk and to enhance the customer experience. We typically collect more than 30,000 data points per monthly active customer, which we use to better understand their behavior, risks and financial needs, enabling us to deliver personalized credit strategies and offer the best product for each customer&#180;s specific financial situation. By using our unique data and advanced NuXCredit Engine, we underwrite customers and manage credit risk with a focus on optimizing long-term Net Present Value (NPV), rather than focusing on short-term Non-performing Loans (NPLs). This allows us to pursue sustainable and resilient growth while complying with Nu's risk appetite. Our 90-day consumer finance delinquency rate (NPL ratio), as of December 2024, was 7.0%. This indicator may not be directly comparable to market figures as the customer and product mix vary significantly among institutions. In our operations in Mexico and Colombia, we expect, based on internal estimates, that delinquency levels may be higher than in Brazil due to a higher share of the interest earning portfolio relative to the total outstanding credit card portfolio, along with each market&#8217;s unique characteristics and overall credit penetration. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 75 &#160; &#160; In Mexico, our non-performing loan share of our loan book is similar to levels seen among Sociedades Financieras Populares (Sofipos), including Fintech players whose metrics are structurally higher than reported by incumbents, according to CNBV data and our internal analysis. We believe that low credit card adoption rates and a relatively high unbanked population in the country are partly responsible for this discrepancy, and we expect the gap to narrow as financial inclusion rises. In Colombia, where financial inclusion is comparatively higher than in Mexico, and based on data available for a limited number of digital subsidiaries of incumbent players serving primarily less affluent segments, our overall credit risk levels are close to the market average for such comparable players. C. &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Credit to SMEs According to the BCB, the country&#8217;s credit portfolios related to SME&#8217;s and MEI&#8217;s (individual microentrepreneur) averaged US$206 billion during the period between January and November 2024, growing 6% on a FX-neutral basis over 2023. This is a market that has been gaining attention in recent years, as it has historically received less focus than the Corporate sector and typically lacks the same level of service customization offered to the retail sector. Nubank has been carefully developing solutions especially for MEIs, Micro and Small companies as this market evolves. &#160; Brazil MSME Credit Portfolio by Company Size (US$ billion) Company Size 2023 average 2024 average YoY Growth (% FXN) Micro or "Microempresa (ME)" 17 16 3% Small or &#8220;Empresa de Pequeno Porte (EPP)&#8221; 70 66 2% Medium or &#8220;Empresa de M&#233;dio Porte&#8221; 115 115 8% Total MSME and MEI 210 206 6% Notes: Exchange rates: BRL 5.00 is equivalent to USD 1.00 for 2023 data; and &#8203;BRL 5.39 to USD 1.00 for 2024 data, respectively. FXN refers to the year-on-year variation in local currency as described in Presentation of Financial and Other Information . Source: BCB (November 2024 data). According to SEBRAE, there were 19.7 million SMEs in Brazil, defined as companies with less than US$889,878 in annual revenue, as of 2024. Within this total, microenterprises accounted for 11.7 million businesses, in which the individual entrepreneur has no more than one employee and annual revenue does not exceed US$15,017. The activities of MEIs are broadly diversified, but for the most part these micro entrepreneurs are active in retail commerce (i.e., apparel, food and other products) and retail services (i.e., repair services and others). As such, they seek banking services that are simple, transparent and fairly priced to meet the day-to-day needs of their businesses. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 76 &#160; &#160; Our business account is designed specifically for customers who run businesses. We provide a business checking account and business prepaid card, offer unlimited wire transfers and allow customers to issue boletos to receive payments from customers, all free of charge. As of December 2024, our PJ account in Brazil had 4.7 million SME customers, an increase of 31% compared to December 2023. According to our internal analysis, we are among the five largest MSE (Micro and Small Enterprises) players in Brazil by number of clients, reaching approximately 24% of all CNPJs registered in the country, according to BCB data. D. Customer Assets Account As of December 31, 2024, the number of unique customers with accounts in Brazil reached more than 199 million, an increase of 2.9% compared to 194 million as of December 31, 2023. More than 47 % of these individuals had an active account with us as of December 31, 2024, compared to 42 % on December 31, 2023. This performance confirms the strong presence of the NuAccount (and our brand) in Brazil. We estimate that, as of December 31, 2024, Brazil had US$ 387 billion in customer deposits, including demand, time and savings deposits, a 12 % FX-neutral increase compared to US$374 billion as of December 31, 2023. Time deposits grew 19%, demand deposits grew 15% and savings grew 5%, compared to December 31, 2023, according to the ANBIMA, the BCB, and internal analyses. With Cuenta Nu in Mexico, which reached 1 million customers within one month of its official launch in May 2023, and more than 8 million as of December 2024, Nubank seeks to contribute to financial inclusion in Latin America's second largest market. Mexico remains significantly underpenetrated in terms of financial services and cash remains by far the most used payment method with a 38% share, as per Worldpay's &#8220;The 2024 Global Payments Report&#8221;. Our long-term strategy is to drive a shift from cash to digital payments. To accelerate this transition, our core value proposition is to offer new customers attractive deposit yields. Our alliances with Arcus, by Mastercard, which began on March 12, 2024, and OXXO, which began on January 13, 2025, represent significant progress in expanding our cash-in and cash-out network, which reached over 30,000 physical contact points in January, 2025. This trend is further reinforced by increased competition from fintech players introducing new products, including no-fee services, attractive deposit yields, alternative transaction and savings options, more cash-in and cash-out functionalities, among others. In Colombia, as of 2023, almost 81% of the adult population held a savings account according to the SFC's Financial Inclusion Report. As seen in Brazil and in Mexico, Nubank and other fintech players are offering attractive yields on savings account deposits to accelerate customer base growth and cross-sell attractive complementary financial services over time. After launching Cuenta Nu in early 2024, we reached almost 2 million account holders in Colombia within one year, as of December 31, 2024. Investments Brazil had almost 98 million active securities accounts on December 31, 2024, up 22 % from 80.4 million on December 31, 2023, and 80.4 million savings accounts in the same period, up 2% year over year according to ANBIMA. Financial assets of Brazilian retail investors, which excludes the private segment, reached US$ 961 billion as of December 31, 2024, a 12 % FX-neutral increase over 2023 according to the BCB, ANBIMA, and our internal analyses. This total includes customer deposits, funds, equities, fixed income and pension funds. Fixed income remains the largest product, representing 35% of that total, followed by pension funds, savings deposits and investment funds (each holding a 19% share), while equities accounted for 4% of the total, same as other general investment categories. Growth of total retail assets was driven primarily by fixed income, with a 16% rise over 2023, reflecting the elevated policy rate outlook in Brazil. Despite this restrictive monetary policy environment, other retail investments also posted nominal FX-neutral gains of 9 % in the year, with investment funds expanding 18% and pension funds increasing close to 11%, outperforming the 10% decline in equity investments. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 77 &#160; &#160; With regard to individual deposits and retail investor assets in Brazil, our estimated market share was 3.3 % on December 31, 2024, compared to 3.0% market share on December 31, 2023. E. Insurance Brokerage In our view, the retail insurance brokerage segment in Latin America has been largely dominated by incumbent banks, many of which also own the underwriting business and therefore favor their own products. We believe this segment is also prone to disruption and is likely to experience strong growth. The Brazilian insurance sector recorded gross written premiums (GWP) across all segments totaling US$73 billion in 2024 according to CNSEG data, and US$25 billion from life insurance, auto, health and other property &amp; casualty products. Despite its size, Brazil remains fairly underpenetrated relative to other developing and developed economies, in both the life and property &amp; casualty segments. Nu is initially focused on market segments characterized by policies sold directly to individuals, representing 60% to 70% of the total GWP, according to Susep and internal estimates. In our view, life insurance distribution to individuals in Brazil remains primarily through the bancassurance channel, while P&amp;C insurance distribution remains concentrated in the broker channel. We believe that complexity, lack of transparency and high premiums, largely a result of inefficient underwriting, continue to prevent many Latin Americans from purchasing more insurance products. Our first insurance product, NuLife, launched in August 2020 (in partnership with Chubb as underwriter), highlights the significant unmet demand for insurance products. NuLife offers flexible, fully customizable life insurance policies that can be contracted in five simple steps through our app. We launched mobile insurance in 2022, and auto and "Vidas Juntas" insurance &#8211; life insurance for non-consanguineum and non-marital relationships &#8211; products in 2023. Our most recent products also are characterized by fully customizable quotes and seamless digital onboarding through Nu&#8217;s app. As of December 2024, we had more than two million active policies across all insurance categories, representing an annual growth rate of 60%. Over time, we plan to broaden our insurance offering to include additional life and P&amp;C products. F. E-Commerce Marketplaces Brazilian e-commerce reached a gross merchandise volume (GMV) of almost US$ 38 billion in 2024, according to the Brazilian Association of E-Commerce (ABCOMM). In 2024, we continued to grow our GMV and expanded our Marketplace to include a broader range of products, enabling Nubank customers to access more compelling offers and further improving the user experience. We launched our UV-exclusive travel experience, allowing customers to book flights and hotels directly within our app through our partnership with Hopper. In September 2024, we unveiled our partnership with the Apple store, offering exclusive deals for Nubank+ and UV customers, combined with special financing conditions through NuPay making iPhones financially accessible to many of our customers for the first time. We also introduced significant enhancements to the user experience, including new features such as merchant-funded coupons, increased personalization, and an expanded product offering - all accessible directly within the app. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 78 &#160; &#160; Revenue by Geography For the year ended December 31, 2024, the majority of our revenue was derived from Brazil, totaling US$8,409.9 million, compared to US$523.1 million in Mexico and US$111.8 million in Colombia (and increase from US$2,681.2, US$168,2 million and US$36,4 million, respectively, for in the year ended December 31, 2023). Customer Demographics We believe our platform both supports customers across the age spectrum and has a particularly strong appeal to younger generations. We believe we serve a larger share of younger consumers than both digital banks and incumbent banks. Our young and expanding customer base represents a significant opportunity for growth. As of December 31, 2024, our customer base in Brazil had a significantly higher concentration of younger users compared to the system-wide average. As a result, our credit exposure also reflected this demographic skew, according to BCB data from March and December 31, 2023. Our Competitive Landscape We believe we are redefining how consumers engage with financial products and services and contributing to market expansion. At the same time, we continue to face competition from other firms, including large incumbent financial institutions, major technology companies, and smaller emerging fintech entrants. We believe the key competitive factors in our market include: &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; our deeply embedded culture of customer-centricity; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; product quality, features and functionality; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; operating leverage and efficiency; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; access to top-tier engineering, data science and product talent; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; brand recognition and affinity; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; security, privacy and trust; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; a scalable product and technology platform; and &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; regulatory licenses. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 79 &#160; &#160; We believe our ability to innovate at speed is a key differentiator that sets our platform apart. We believe we compete favorably across these critical dimensions and have developed a business model that is difficult to replicate. Our Road Ahead Nu remains in the early stages of leading a significant transformation in financial services in Latin America and globally. Despite our remarkable growth trajectory, we currently capture only a fraction of financial services revenue worldwide, highlighting the vast opportunity still ahead. As we look forward, Nu continues to prioritize responsible and ambitious growth over short-term earnings gains. We outline our path forward presenting the &#8216;Three-Act Story.&#8217; Act 1: Building the Largest and Most Loved Retail Banking Franchise in Latin America. This is our current focus, with most resources dedicated here. Even achieving significant scale, our market share is still under 6% in revenue terms. We will continue to nurture customer love, scale our credit operations, and increase principality in Brazil, Mexico and Colombia, all while providing a seamless, fast, and reliable app experience. Act 2: Expand Beyond Financial Services. We began this journey with marketplace, travel, and, more recently, telecom. With a large and highly engaged customer base, one of the most loved and trusted brands in Brazil, and strong data and cross-sell capabilities, we believe we have earned the right to expand beyond traditional financial services. Our goal is to create an ecosystem that broadens our addressable market and empowers customers to optimize their spending, setting the stage for new verticals. Act 3: A Global AI-Driven Digital Banking Model. This represents our long-term vision to evolve our regional digital banking platform into a global model, leveraging AI to offer financial products and services to millions that were once limited to a select few. In 2025, we will take crucial steps to realize this vision by setting the foundations to support global-scale products and services. &#160; Recent Developments Tyme Investments On December 12, 2024 Nu made a minority investment in Tyme Group Pte Ltd. ("Tyme") acting as lead investor in its series D funding round. Tyme operates under a hybrid model that combines a customer-centric digital platform with physical experiences, delivered in partnership with nationwide retailers through digital kiosks and bank ambassadors. Tyme specializes in emerging markets, including South Africa and the Philippines. For additional details, refer to note 18 of our financial statements. Nucoin In September 2024, we announced the strategic repositioning of Nucoin as part of a new loyalty program under development for Nubank customers. This transition led to the discontinuation of the liquidity pool feature that previously enabled clients to buy and sell Nucoin. As a result, we recorded a US$40 million, primarily attributed to marketing expenses, aimed at repositioning Nucoin within the new loyalty program, as well as US$8 million attributable to the impairment expenses of certain capitalized intangible assets associated with the liquidity pool feature. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 80 &#160; &#160; United States International Development Finance, or &#8220;DFC&#8221;, facility On September 27, 2024, our Colombian subsidiary signed an agreement of a 3-year credit facility of up to US$ 150.0 million with DFC (United States International Development Finance), guaranteed by Nu Holdings. The facility aims to support the growth of our operations in Colombia. For more details about the transaction, please refer to &#8220;item 5. Operating and Financial Review and Prospects-B. Liquidity and Capital Resources - Borrowings and financing&#8221;. Regulatory Overview Brazil Our Regulatory Position Four of our subsidiaries in Brazil, Nu Pagamentos S.A. &#8211; Institui&#231;&#227;o de Pagamento, or &#8220;Nu Pagamentos,&#8221; Nu Financeira S.A. &#8211; Sociedade de Cr&#233;dito, Financiamento e Investimento, or &#8220;Nu Financeira,&#8221; NuPay for Business Institui&#231;&#227;o de Pagamento Ltda, or &#8220;NuPay&#8221;, and Nu Investimentos S.A. - Corretora de T&#237;tulos e Valores Mobili&#225;rios or &#8220;Nu Investimentos,&#8221; are subject to regulation enacted by the Central Bank of Brazil (BCB), the Brazilian Securities and Exchange Commission (CVM) and/or the National Monetary Council (CMN), as applicable and have received the required authorizations to operate, as follows: &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Nu Pagamentos is authorized by the BCB to operate as a payment institution in the capacities of (1) issuer of postpaid payment instruments ( emissor de instrumento de pagamento p&#243;s-pago ), (2) issuer of electronic currency (emissor de moeda eletr&#244;nica), (3) acquirer ( credenciador ) and (4) payment initiation service provider ( iniciador de transa&#231;&#227;o de pagamento ); &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Nu Financeira is authorized by the BCB to operate as a credit, financing and investment entity ( sociedade de cr&#233;dito, financiamento e investimento ), conducting active, passive and ancillary transactions related to credit, financing and investment portfolios; &#9679; NuPay is authorized by the BCB to operate as a payment institution in the capacity of issuer of electronic currency ( emissor de moeda eletr&#244;nica ); &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Nu Investimentos is authorized (1) by the BCB to operate as a securities broker ( corretora de t&#237;tulos e valores mobili&#225;rios , or &#8220;CTVM&#8221;), performing the activities provided in CMN Resolution No. 5.008, of March 24, 2022, as amended, or Resolution No. 5.008/22 and (2) by CVM to (i) provide investments fund bookkeeping services (ii) offer securities custody services and (iii) coordinate securities offerings. In addition, Nu Asset Management Ltda., (Nu Asset Management) a wholly owned subsidiary of Nu Investimentos, is authorized by the CVM to provide securities portfolio management services. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 81 &#160; &#160; One of our subsidiaries, Nu Corretora de Seguros Ltda., or &#8220;Nu Corretora de Seguros&#8221; is regulated by Superintendence of Private Insurance (SUSEP) and is authorised to operate as an insurance brokerage firm under applicable Brazilian regulations. None of our Brazilian subsidiaries are licensed to operate as a bank. Regulatory Environment in Brazil Our main subsidiaries in Brazil are subject to extensive regulation, such as those applicable to payment institutions (such as Nu Pagamentos and Nu Pay), financial institutions (Nu Financeira), securities and brokers (Nu Investimentos), securities portfolio manager (Nu Asset Management) and insurance brokers (Nu Corretora de Seguros). We offer various payment, financial and capital markets services; in particular, we conduct activities related to payments, digital accounts, brokerage services, portfolio management and insurance. Legislation Applicable to the Brazilian Payment System General The activities carried out by Nu Pagamentos in Brazil are subject to Brazilian laws and regulations applicable to payment institutions, particularly Law No. 12,865 of October 9, 2013, or the &#8220;Payments Law,&#8221; which, in short, regulates payment institutions and payment schemes that are part of the Brazilian Payment System (the Sistema de Pagamentos Brasileiro , or the &#8220;SPB&#8221;). Payment Institutions A payment institution is defined as the legal entity that participates in one or more payment schemes and is dedicated, exclusively or otherwise, to the execution of fund transfers, among other related activities, as described in the Payments Law. Specifically, under the Brazilian payment regulations, payment institutions are categorized into one of the following four categories: &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Issuers of electronic currency (prepaid payment instruments): these institutions manage prepaid payment accounts, enable payment transactions using electronic currency stored in such prepaid payment accounts, and convert those funds into physical or book-entry currency, or vice versa. &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Issuers of post-paid payment instruments (e.g., credit cards): these institutions manage payment accounts that enable end-users to make payments on a post-paid basis. &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Acquirers: these institutions do not manage payment accounts, but (i) enable merchants to accept payment instruments issued by a payment institution or by a financial institution within the same payment scheme; and (ii) participate in the settlement process as creditor of the issuer of the payment instrument. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 82 &#160; &#160; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Payment initiation service providers (PISP): these payment institutions render initial payment services whereby they do not (1) manage the payment or checking account from which the payment is executed; nor (2) hold the transferred funds during the rendering of their services. Payment institutions that operate in Brazil must comply with several legal and regulatory requirements set forth by CMN and the Central Bank of Brazil, as applicable, which may vary according to certain features of their specific business models and to thresholds defined by the regulation, such as the volume of payment transactions processed and/or the amount of funds held in prepaid payment accounts during the previous twelve months. Therefore, certain payment institutions may not be subject to the full legal and regulatory framework applicable to the payment industry in Brazil such as the ones that only participate in limited-purpose payment schemes or provide services in the scope of programs set up by governmental authorities aimed at granting benefits to individuals due to employment relationships. CMN and Central Bank of Brazil regulations applicable to payment institutions cover a wide variety of matters, including, but not limited to risk management, governance, anti-money laundering and combating the financing of terrorism, cybersecurity, secrecy, ombudsman, internal audit, reporting obligations and governance. In addition, payment institutions must seek approval from the Central Bank of Brazil when appointing managers (including directors, officers and members of certain statutory boards, such as fiscal councils). The regulations applicable to payment institutions also cover &#8220;payment accounts&#8221; ( contas de pagamento ), which are the end-user accounts, in registered (i.e., book-entry) form, which are opened with payment institutions that are card issuers of prepaid or post- paid instruments and used for carrying out each payment transaction. Current regulations classify payment accounts as follows: &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Prepaid payment accounts: the intended payment transaction is executed only when the funds have already been deposited into the payment account; and &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Post-paid payment accounts: the intended payment transaction is executed regardless of whether funds are deposited into the payment account. To provide protection from bankruptcy, the Payments Law requires payment institutions that issue electronic currency to segregate prepaid payment account funds from their own assets. These institutions must hold the total balance of prepaid funds in certain specified instruments: either (1) a non-interest-bearing account with the Central Bank of Brazil; or (2) in federal government bonds registered with the SELIC. Since July 1, 2023, payment institutions have also been permitted to operate in the foreign exchange market, provided they comply with certain restrictions such as operating only with electronic currency and adhering to operational thresholds set forth by the Central Bank of Brazil Resolution No. 277/22, and subject to prior authorization. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 83 &#160; &#160; Payment Schemes According to the Payments Law, a payment scheme, for regulatory purposes in Brazil, is the collection of rules and procedures that governs payment services provided to the public, with direct access by its end-users (i.e., payers and receivers). In addition, such payment services must be accepted by more than one receiver in order to qualify as a payment scheme. The regulations applicable to payment schemes depend on certain features, such as the volume of users and the amount of transactions processed therein: &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Payment schemes that exceed certain thresholds are considered part of SPB and are subject to the legal and regulatory framework applicable to the payment industry in Brazil, including the requirement to obtain a license to operate by the Central Bank of Brazil. &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Payment schemes that operate below these thresholds are not considered to form part of the SPB and are therefore not subject to the legal and regulatory framework applicable to the payment industry in Brazil, including the requirement to obtain an authorization from the Central Bank of Brazil, although they are required to report certain operational information to the Central Bank of Brazil on an annual basis. &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Limited-purpose payment schemes are not considered to form part of the SPB and, therefore, are not subject to the legal and regulatory framework applicable to the payment industry in Brazil, including the requirement to obtain authorization from the Central Bank of Brazil. Limited-purpose payment schemes are, for instance, those whose payment orders are: (i) accepted only at the network of merchants that clearly display the same visual identity as that of the issuer, such as franchisees and other merchants licensed to use the issuer&#8217;s brand; (ii) intended for payment of specific public utility services, such as public transport and public telecommunications; or (iii) accepted exclusively within a closed-loop payment scheme and for the payment of one type of product or service, of a restricted set of products or services related with a specific activity or market. &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Depending on the type of payment instrument, the payment scheme will not be considered part of the SPB as well. This is the case of payments of employment benefits and meal or food vouchers. &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Certain types of payment schemes have specific exemptions from the requirement to obtain authorization from the Central Bank of Brazil. This applies, for example, to payment schemes established by governmental authorities, specific financial institutions, or authorized payment institutions, as well as those aimed at granting benefits to individuals due to employment relationships. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 84 &#160; &#160; Payment Scheme Settler A payment scheme is established and operated by a payment scheme settler, which is the legal entity responsible for its authorization and function. Under Brazilian regulations, payment scheme settlers, accountable for managing the rules, procedures and brand usage associated with a payment scheme. Central Bank of Brazil regulations require that payment scheme settlers must be (i) incorporated in Brazil, (ii) have a corporate purpose compatible with its payments activities; and (iii) have the technical, operational, organizational, administrative and financial capacity to meet their obligations. They must also maintain clear and effective corporate governance mechanisms suited to the needs of both payment institutions and end users of payment schemes. Legislation Applicable to Financial Institutions and Portfolio Managers General Rules The Banking Law, laid out the structure of the Brazilian National Financial System, made up of the CMN, the Central Bank of Brazil, Banco do Brasil S.A., BNDES and other public or private financial institutions. Law No. 4,728 of July 14, 1965, as amended, or &#8220;Law No. 4,728/65,&#8221; regulates Brazilian capital markets through setting standards and various other mechanisms. Further, pursuant to Law No. 6,385 of December 7, 1976, as amended, or &#8220;Law No. 6,385/76,&#8221; the distribution and issuance of securities in the market, trading of securities and settlement and/or clearance of securities transactions all require prior authorization by the CVM. Brazil&#180;s financial and capital markets regulatory framework is further supplemented by the regulations enacted by CMN, CVM and/or the Central Bank of Brazil, as applicable. This framework also incorporates self-regulation policies, including rules enacted by various associations, over-the-counter organized markets and securities exchanges that govern the activities of their members and participants, such as B3, ANBIMA, and the Brazilian Association of Investment Analysts (APIMEC). The incorporation and operation of financial institutions and other regulated entities that intend to operate in the Brazilian financial and/or capital markets are subject to prior licensing, regulation and oversight from the Central Bank of Brazil. Other corporate events such as capital increases, appointment of officers, changes in corporate control, among others, may also be subject to prior authorization. Financial institutions in Brazil may operate as commercial banks, investment banks, credit, financing and investment companies, cooperative banks, leasing companies, real estate credit companies, mortgage companies, among others. Each is regulated by specific rules issued by the CMN, the Central Bank of Brazil, and, if such financial institutions participate in capital markets activities, the CVM. Likewise, stock exchanges must comply with CMN, Central Bank of Brazil, and CVM regulations, as well in accordance with Law No. 4,728/65. Pursuant to Banking Law, CMN Resolution No. 4,970 of November 25, 2021, as amended, or &#8220;CMN Resolution No. 4,970,&#8221; financial institutions must seek approval from the Central Bank of Brazil, and, in certain cases, from the CVM when appointing managers (including directors, officers and members of certain statutory boards, such as fiscal councils). Moreover, under Law No. 4,728/65, managers of securities brokerage firms are subject to further restrictions and are prohibited from working for or fulfilling any administrative, advisory, tax or decision-making positions at entities whose securities are traded on the stock exchange. These managers are also barred from holding managerial positions at other brokerage firms authorized to carry out foreign exchange transactions pursuant to CMN Resolution No. 5,009 of March, 24, 2022. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 85 &#160; &#160; In addition, the Banking Law imposes restrictions on loans and cash advances from financial institutions to their managers (officers, directors, and members of advisory boards, as well as their relatives). These restrictions are governed by CMN Resolution No. 4,693 of October 29, 2018. Credit, Financing and Investment Institutions (Consumer Credit Companies) Credit, financing and investment institutions ( sociedades de cr&#233;dito, financiamento e investimento ), such as Nu Financeira, also referred to as &#8220;financeiras&#8221; or &#8220;SCFI&#8221;, are financial institutions that are part of the national financial system and subject to regulation and oversight by the CMN and the Central Bank of Brazil. These entities were established under Ordinance No. 309 of the Ministry of Finance, dated November 30, 1959, and operate as private financial institutions whose basic objective is to carry out financing for the acquisition of goods and services, as well as for working capital. Consumer credit companies must be incorporated as corporations ( sociedade por a&#231;&#245;es ) and their corporate name must include the designation &#8220;Cr&#233;dito, Financiamento e Investimento&#8221; (credit, financing and investment). SCFIs are not allowed to offer deposit accounts. However, such institutions can raise funds through the issuance of bank deposit certificates, or CDBs ( Certificado de Dep&#243;sito Banc&#225;rio ) or by accepting deposits without issuance of certificates, known as RDB ( Recibo de Dep&#243;sito Banc&#225;rio ), among other instruments. Both CDB and RDB are fixed income securities subject to the ordinary guarantee from the FGC ( Fundo Garantidor de Cr&#233;dito , the Brazilian credit guarantee fund). The key distinction between them lies in the fact that the RDB is non-transferable and non-tradable. Many credit, financing and investment institutions operate as the financial arm of non-banking economic groups. In our case, Nu Financeira provides revolving credit and transactional financing to our credit card holders, offers personal loans and issues instruments such as RDB to support the funding of our operation. Securities Brokerage and Distribution Firms Securities trading in stock exchange markets shall be carried out exclusively by DTVMs, CTVMs (such as Nu Investimentos) and certain other authorized institutions. Securities distributors (distribuidoras de t&#237;tulos e valores mobili&#225;rios) and securities brokers ( corretoras de t&#237;tulos e valores mobili&#225;rios ) are regulated by Resolution No. 5,008/22. Pursuant to joint decision No. 17, of March 2, 2009, issued by the Central Bank of Brazil and the CVM, distributors were authorised to operate directly within the environments and trading systems of organized stock exchange markets. This effectively eliminated the operational distinctions between securities brokers and distributors, and such institutions are today allowed to perform practically the same operations. In this regard, Resolution No. 5,008/22 allows brokerage firms to participate, among others, in the following activities: (1) trading in stock exchanges; (2) managing investment portfolios; (3) providing custody services; and (4) issuing electronic currency and managing pre-paid payment accounts. In addition to Resolution No. 5,008/22, which repealed Resolution No. 4,871, brokerage firms are subject to oversight by the CVM. Under the rules set forth by the Central Bank of Brazil, brokerage firms (such as Nu Investimentos) are prohibited from executing transactions that may result in loans, facilities or cash advances to customers, including through synthetic transactions (such as an assignment of rights), with the exception of margin transactions and other limited transactions. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 86 &#160; &#160; Moreover, brokerage firms can neither charge commissions in connection with trades during primary distribution, nor purchase real estate, except for their own use or when acquired as settlement for &#8220;bad debts&#8221;, provided such assets are sold within a year. Third-Party Asset Management Nu Asset Management is an asset manager accredited to operate by, and subject to the rules and oversight of, the CVM, pursuant to Law No. 6,385/76 and CVM Resolution No. 21 of February 25, 2021, as amended, or &#8220;CVM Resolution No. 21&#8221;. Verios Asset Management, a former affiliate, is no longer under CVM oversight, following its deregistration from the CVM in November 2021. CVM Resolution No. 21 defines asset and portfolio management activities as professional activities, directly or indirectly related to the operation, maintenance and management of securities portfolios, including the investment of client funds in the securities market. Under CVM Resolution No. 21, asset managers are classified into two categories: (1) trustee administrator and/or (2) portfolio manager. Nu Asset Management is registered as a portfolio manager. To be authorized to act as an asset manager by the CVM, under CVM Resolution 21, a legal entity must meet several requirements, including: (i) having a registered office in Brazil; (ii) having securities portfolio management as a corporate purpose and being duly incorporated and registered with the National Register of Legal Entities &#8211; CNPJ; (iii) having one or more officers duly certified as asset managers as approved by CVM to assume responsibility for securities portfolio management, pursuant to CVM Resolution No. 21; (iv) appointing a designated officer for portfolio management, a compliance officer and a risk management officer; (5) be controlled by reputable shareholders (direct and indirect), who have not been convicted of certain crimes detailed in article 3, VI of CVM Resolution No. 21; (v) ensuring none of its offices are unable suspended from occupying a position in financial institutions or other entities authorized to operate by the CVM, the Central Bank of Brazil, SUSEP or PREVIC, and have not been banned from asset management activities by judicial or administrative decisions; (vi) implementing adequate personnel and IT resources infrastructure proportionate to the size and complexity of investment portfolio managed; and (vii) execute and provide the applicable forms to the CVM demonstrating operational readiness and regulatory compliance. Pursuant to CVM Resolution No. 21, asset managers are also required to conduct their activities with transparency, in good faith, diligence and loyalty with respect to their customers and perform their duties with the aim of achieving their investment objectives. This same regulation requires asset managers to maintain a website, with extensive up-to-date information, including, but not limited to: (i) an updated annual filing form ( formul&#225;rio de refer&#234;ncia ); (ii) a code of ethics; (iii) rules, procedures and a description of internal controls in order to comply with CVM Resolution No. 21; (iv) a risk management policy; (v) a policy of purchase and sale of securities by managers, employees and the company; (vi) a pricing manual for assets from the securities portfolios managed by such asset manager, even if the manual has been developed by a third party; and (vii) a policy of apportionment and division of orders among the securities portfolios. Moreover, under CVM Resolution No. 21, asset management firms are forbidden to: (i) publicly guarantee or assure profitability levels based on the historical performance of portfolio and market indexes; (ii) modify the essential features of the services they provide without following the prior appropriate procedures under the asset management agreement and regulations; (iii) make promises as to future results of the portfolio; (iv) contract or granting loans on behalf of their customers, subject to certain exceptions set out in regulation; (v) provide a surety, corporate guarantee, acceptance or becoming a joint obligor in any other form, with respect to the managed assets; (vi) neglecting, under any circumstances, customers&#8217; rights and intentions; (vii) engage in trading securities held in managed portfolios with the purpose of obtaining brokerage revenue or rebates for themselves or third parties; or (viii) acting as a counterparty to clients, directly or indirectly, except as permitted by applicable regulations. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 87 &#160; &#160; Insurance Brokerage Firms Insurance brokerage firms, such as Nu Corretora de Seguros Ltda. (formerly known as Easy CS) must obtain registration and authorization for their operations, pursuant to the rules in force and in accordance with Law No. 4,594 of December 29, 1964, as amended, or &#8220;Law No. 4,594/64,&#8221; and Decree-Law No. 73/66 (as well as regulation issued by the CNSP and SUSEP). The insurance brokers, whether an individual or legal entity, are legally authorized to act as intermediaries in the solicitation and promotion of insurance contracts, between the insurance companies and individuals or public or private legal entities. Pursuant to Law No. 4,594/64 and applicable SUSEP and CNSP regulations, only duly qualified insurance brokers that have executed an insurance tender shall be paid the brokerage fees related to each insurance line, based on the respective tariffs, including in case of adjustment to the issued premium. Under the applicable regulation, insurance brokerage firms such as Nu Corretora de Seguros Ltda. (Easy CS) must also provide evidence of the technical certification of their employees who act as brokers for offering, for example, insurance claims settlement services, direct sales of insurance, capitalization, open supplementary pension products and others. Such certification shall be issued by an institution of recognized technical capacity, duly accredited by SUSEP. In addition, insurance brokers must also appoint and include a technical officer in the statutory documents for the purpose of representing the entity before SUSEP and for it to be granted its operating license. Insured individuals and insurance companies can pursue civil action against insurance brokers for losses incurred as a result of intentional malfeasance or negligence caused by brokerage activity. In case of non-compliance with the regulatory rules, in addition to the legal sanctions, insurance brokers and managers are subject to fines, temporary suspension from the exercise of the profession or registration cancellation. Crypto Exchange Activities In December 2022, the Brazilian National Congress approved Bill of Law No. 4,401/2021, which was sanctioned by the President as Law No. 14,478/2022, establishing a legal framework for crypto services in Brazil. The law outlines the regulatory guidelines for the provision of virtual asset services and for regulation of virtual asset service providers, or &#8220;VASPs,&#8221; which include, among others, free competition, protection of personal data, protection of popular savings, consumer protection, and anti-money laundering actions. Under this legal framework, VASPs are defined as legal entities that on behalf of third parties, provide at least one of the following services: (i) exchange between virtual assets and domestic or foreign currency; (ii) exchange between one or more virtual assets; (iii) transfer of virtual assets; (iv) safe-keeping or management of virtual assets or instruments enabling a control over virtual assets; or (v) participation in financial services and the rendering of services in connection with an issue offering or sale of virtual assets. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 88 &#160; &#160; In connection with Law No. 14,478/2022, Decree No. 11,563 published on June 14, 2023, regulates the virtual assets market law and designates the Central Bank of Brazil as the authority in charge of regulating and overseeing this market within the scope of the said law, with authority to: (i) regulate the provision of virtual asset services, (ii) regulate, authorize and oversee the VASPs, and (iii) address other matters prescribed by said law, excluding the matters relating to the National Register of Politically Exposed Persons, or &#8220;CNPEP,&#8221; introduced by Law No. 14,478/2022. The decree stresses that the powers and authority of the CVM, tasked with regulating the issuance and offering of those virtual assets classified as securities under Law No. 6,385 of 1976, remain unchanged. The decree and Law No. 14,478/2022 both came into effect on June 20, 2023. Subsequently, on November 8 and 29, 2024, the Central Bank of Brazil issued Public Consultations No. 109, 110 and 111, proposing a regulatory framework for VASPs which is further detailed below under &#8220;&#8212;Recent Developments in Brazil &#8212;Virtual Assets and Virtual Assets Service Providers.&#8221; Main Regulatory Authorities in Brazil National Financial System The primary regulatory authorities overseeing the Brazilian financial system are CMN, the Central Bank of Brazil and CVM. Additionally, most Brazilian securities brokers, securities distributors and asset managers are associated with and subject to the self-regulatory standards established by ANBIMA. In addition, trading segments managed by B3 are also subject to self-regulation and oversight by BSM &#8211; Supervis&#227;o de Mercados, or &#8220;BSM,&#8221; a non-profit organization that forms part of the B3 group. Below is a summary of the main duties and powers of each regulatory agent, ANBIMA and BSM. CMN CMN is the main monetary and financial policy authority in Brazil, responsible for creating financial, credit, budgetary and monetary rules. Brazil&#180;s current banking and financial institutional framework was established by Law No. 4,595 of December 31, 1964, as amended, or the &#8220;Banking Law.&#8221; According to Banking Law, the CMN&#8217;s main responsibilities are to oversee the regular organization, operation and inspection of entities that are subject to the Banking Law, as well as the enforcement of applicable penalties. In addition, Law No. 4,728/65 delegates to the CMN the power to set general rules for underwriting activities for resale, distribution or intermediation in the placement of securities, including rules governing the minimum regulatory capital of the companies that contemplate the underwriting for resale and distribution of instruments in the market and conditions for registration of the companies or individual firms which contemplate intermediation activities in the distribution of instruments in the market. The CMN has the power to regulate credit transactions involving Brazilian financial institutions and Brazilian currency, supervise the foreign exchange and gold reserves of Brazil, establish saving and investment policies in Brazil and regulate the Brazilian capital markets. The CMN also oversees the activities of the Central Bank of Brazil, the CVM and SUSEP. Other CMN responsibilities include: &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; coordinating monetary, credit, budget and public debt policies; &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 89 &#160; &#160; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; establishing policies on foreign exchange and interest rates; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; seeking to ensure liquidity and solvency of financial institutions; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; overseeing activities related to the stock exchange markets; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; regulating the structure and operation of financial institutions; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; granting authority to the Central Bank of Brazil to issue currency and establish reserve requirement levels; and &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; establishing general guidelines for the banking and financial markets. Central Bank of Brazil The activities of financial institutions are subject to limitations and restrictions. The Central Bank of Brazil is responsible for: (i) implementing CMN policies related to monetary, credit and foreign exchange control matters; (ii) regulating Brazilian financial institutions in the public and private sectors; and (iii) monitoring and regulating foreign investments in Brazil. The President of the Central Bank of Brazil is appointed by the President of Brazil (subject to ratification by the Senate) for a four-year term, always beginning on January 1 of the third year of the President of Brazil&#180;s term in office. The Banking Law delegated to the Central Bank of Brazil the responsibility of permanently overseeing companies that directly or indirectly interfere in the financial and capital markets, controlling such companies&#8217; operations in the foreign exchange market through operational proceedings and various modalities, and supervising the relative stability of foreign exchange rates and balance of payments. In addition, Law No. 4,728/65 states that the CMN and the Central Bank of Brazil shall exercise their duties related to the financial and capital markets with the purpose of, among other things, facilitating the public&#8217;s access to information related to bonds or securities traded in the market and on the companies that issue them, protecting investors against illegal or fraudulent issuances of bonds or securities, preventing fraud and manipulation modalities intended to create artificial conditions of the demand, supply or pricing of bonds or securities distributed in the markets and ensuring the observance of equitable commercial practices by all of those professionals who participate in the intermediation of the distribution or trading of bonds or securities. The Central Bank of Brazil has authority over brokerage firms, financial institutions, companies or individual firms performing underwriting for resale and distribution of bonds or securities, and maintains a record on, and inspects the transactions of, companies or individual firms that carry out intermediation activities in the distribution of bonds or securities, or which conduct, for any purposes, the prospecting of popular savings in the capital market. Other key responsibilities of the Central Bank of Brazil include: &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; controlling and approving the organization, operation, transfer of control and corporate reorganization of financial institutions and other institutions authorized to operate by the Central Bank of Brazil; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; managing the daily flow of foreign capital and derivatives; &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 90 &#160; &#160; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; establishing administrative rules and regulation for the registration of foreign investments; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; monitoring remittances of foreign currency; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; controlling the repatriation of funds (in the event of a serious deficit in Brazil&#8217;s payment balance, the Central Bank of Brazil may limit remittances of profits and prohibit remittances of capital for a limited period); &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; receiving compulsory collections and voluntary deposits in cash from financial institutions; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; executing rediscount transactions and granting loans to banking financial institutions and other institutions authorized to operate by the Central Bank of Brazil; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; intervening in the financial institutions or placing them under special administrative regimes, and determining their compulsory liquidation; and &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; acting as depositary of gold and foreign currency. CVM The CVM is Brazil&#180;s federal securities regulator, responsible for implementing the CMN&#8217;s policies related to the capital market and for overseeing the regulation, development, supervision of the securities market. The main responsibilities of the CVM include: &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; regulating the Brazilian capital markets, in accordance with Brazilian corporation law and securities law; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; setting rules governing the operation of the securities market; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; defining the types of financial institutions that may carry out activities in the securities market, as well as the kinds of transactions that they may perform and services that they may provide in such market; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; controlling and supervising the Brazilian securities market through, among others: &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; approving, suspending and delisting publicly held companies; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; authorizing brokerage firms to operate in the securities market and public offering of securities; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; supervising publicly held companies, stock exchange markets, commodities and futures markets, financial investment funds and variable income funds; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; enforcing full disclosure of relevant events that affect the market, as well as the publication of annual and quarterly reports by publicly held companies; &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 91 &#160; &#160; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; imposing penalties; and &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; permanently monitoring the activities and services of the securities market, as well as the dissemination of information related to the market and the amounts traded therein to market participants. The CVM also regulates and supervises financial investment funds and derivatives markets, a role previously fulfilled by the Central Bank of Brazil. These responsibilities were transferred to the CVM under Law No. 10,198 of February 14, 2001, as amended, and Law No. 10,303 of October 31, 2001. In compliance with Brazilian legislation, the CVM is governed by a President and four officers, all of whom are appointed by the President of Brazil and subject to Senate approval. The persons appointed to the CVM shall have strong reputations and be recognized as experts in the capital markets sector. CVM officers are appointed for a single term of office of five years, and one-fifth of the members are renewed annually. Brazilian Payments System Our activities carried out by Nu Pagamentos are subject to Brazilian laws and regulations relating to payment institutions set forth in Payments Law. The Payments Law grants the Central Bank of Brazil, in accordance with the guidelines set out by the CMN, the authority to regulate entities involved in the payments industry. This authority covers matters such as the operation of these entities, authorization to operate, approval of appointed managers (directors and officers), risk management structures, the opening of payment accounts, and the transfer of funds to and from payment accounts. After the enactment of Payments Law, the CMN and the Central Bank of Brazil created a regulatory framework regulating the operation of payment schemes and payment institutions, which continues to evolve. In this regard, the main responsibilities of the Central Bank of Brazil in relation to the Brazilian payment system include: &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; regulating the setup, operation and monitoring of payment institutions and payment schemes; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; authorizing the setup of payment schemes; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; authorizing the setup, operation, transfer of control, merger, spin-off and consolidation of payment institutions; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; setting conditions and authorizing the appointment of directors and managers in payment institutions; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; supervising payment institutions and schemes and applying sanctions when due; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; adopting preventive measures to ensure soundness, efficiency and ongoing operation of payment schemes and of payment institutions; &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 92 &#160; &#160; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; adopt measures aimed at greater competition, financial inclusion and transparency in the provision of payment services; and &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; regulating fees, commissions or other consideration for payment services, including those charged among members of the same payment arrangement. Pension and Insurance SUSEP and CNSP In Brazil, the regulation of insurance, co-insurance, reinsurance, capitalization, supplementary pension schemes and brokerage is carried out by the CNSP and SUSEP. SUSEP is an independent agency in charge of implementing and conducting the policies established by the CNSP and the supervision of insurance, co-insurance, reinsurance, capitalization, supplementary pension schemes and brokerage. SUSEP neither regulates nor supervises (i) the supplementary pension entities that are regulated by the CNPC; and (ii) the operators of private healthcare assistance plans, which are regulated by ANS. The CNSP is made up of one representative from each of the following bodies: Ministry of Social Security, the Central Bank of Brazil, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Justice, the CVM and the superintendent of SUSEP &#8211; Private Insurance Authority. The supplementary insurance and pension sectors in Brazil are subject to overlapping regulations. Decree-Law No. 73 of November 21, 1966, as amended, sought to centralize the legislation and inspection activities in the sector by creating the National Private Insurance System &#8211; SNSP, composed of (i) CNSP; (ii) SUSEP; (iii) insurance companies duly authorized to operate in the private insurance market; (iv) reinsurance companies; and (v) duly qualified and/or registered insurance brokers. The CNSP, which is linked to the Ministry of Finance, and its main roles include: establishing the guidelines and rules for the private insurance policy in Brazil; regulating the incorporation, organization, operations, and inspection of insurers, reinsurers, supplementary open pension funds, and capitalization companies, as well as establishing capital thresholds for such entities; establishing the general characteristics of insurance and reinsurance contracts; setting the general guidelines for insurance, reinsurance, supplementary open pension funds, and capitalization operations; establishing general accounting and statistical rules, as well as legal, technical, and investment limits for the operations of insurers, reinsurers, supplementary open pension funds, and capitalization companies; and regulating insurance and reinsurance broker activities and profession. SUSEP&#8217;s primary responsibilities include: processing application for incorporation, organization, operations, and inspecting insurers, reinsurers, supplementary open pension funds, and capitalization companies; issuing instructions and circular letters in connection with the regulation of insurance, reinsurance, supplementary open pension funds, and capitalization operations, in accordance with CNSP guidelines; setting forth the conditions of insurance plans to be used by the insurer market; approving limits for the operations of supervised companies; authorizing the use and release of assets and amounts given in guaranty for technical provisions and discretionary capital; inspecting and implementing the general accounting and statistical rules set forth by CNSP; and is responsible for overseeing the operations, and when applicable, the orderly liquidation of supervised companies. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 93 &#160; &#160; Self-Regulatory Entities ANBIMA ANBIMA is a private self-regulatory organization representing investment banks, asset managers, securities brokers and investment advisers. Among its key responsibilities, it establishes rules as well as codes of best practices for the Brazilian capital markets, including enforcing punitive measures in cases of non-compliance with its rules. BSM BSM conducts market surveillance by monitoring transactions, orders and trades executed in B3 trading environments. Its activities include monitoring transactions, orders and trades, market participants, and providing compensation for losses up to a certain threshold. When necessary, BSM may initiate punitive administrative proceedings and enforce sanctions against those who infringe the applicable regulations. In close collaboration with CVM and the Central Bank of Brazil, BSM acts to ensure that institutions and their professionals comply with market regulations, by: &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; conducting market surveillance &#8211; BSM monitors all orders and trades in B3&#8217;s markets in order to identify signs of irregularities; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; auditing &#8211; BSM audits all B3 participants to ensure their compliance with the regulations and to identify possible violations of market rules; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; enforcing compliance through disciplinary actions &#8211; when violations of regulations occur, BSM adopts guidance, persuasion or disciplinary measures such as letters of recommendation, letters of censure or administrative sanctioning proceedings, in accordance with the severity of the violation that has been identified; in addition, BSM can, in connection with administrative sanctioning proceedings, apply penalties to or enter into Terms of Commitment ( termo de compromisso ) with the accused; &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; providing compensation for losses &#8211; BSM analyzes and adjudicates complaints presented to the Investor Compensation Mechanism, or &#8220;MRP&#8221;, which awards damages of up to R$120,000 to investors harmed by a B3 participant&#8217;s inappropriate activity; and &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; facilitating market development &#8211; BSM develops education initiatives, enhancing regulatory frameworks, and fostering relationships with domestic and international regulatory agencies and market stakeholders. APIMEC APIMEC is a private self-regulatory association authorized by the CVM to certify and oversee the self-regulation of securities analysts (both individuals and legal entities). Its responsibilities include establishing rules, procedures and best practices that must be observed by them in the performance of their activities. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 94 &#160; &#160; Other Rules Prudential Framework and Limits of Exposure Financial Institutions Financial institutions in Brazil are subject to an extensive set of rules issued by the CMN and the Central Bank of Brazil related to corporate capital, exposure limits and other solvency requirements that follow principles recommended by the Basel Committee, especially in view of the systemic risks associated with the relationship and activity of financial institutions. In this context, the CMN and the Central Bank of Brazil play a central role in safeguarding the solvency of the National Financial System and mitigating systemic risks. With this aim, CMN Resolution No. 2,099 of August 17, 1994, as amended, or &#8220;CMN Resolution No. 2,099,&#8221; establishes minimum corporate capital and net equity thresholds for various types of financial institutions. For instance, the CMN requires a minimum capital and net equity of R$1.5 million for DTVMs and for CTVMs, such as Nu Investimentos, and R$7.0 million for credit, financing and investment institutions, such as Nu Financeira. For more information regarding prudential aspects and operational limits applicable to the prudential conglomerate led by Nu Pagamentos, see &#8220;&#8212;Other Rules&#8212;Payment Institutions&#8221; below. Capital Requirements for Operational Risks On November 28, 2023, the Central Bank of Brazil released Resolution No. 356, which replaced the three prior methodologies used to calculate the Risk Weighted Asset, or "RWA", component for operational risk, or &#8220;RWAOpad,&#8221; which was in use (BIA, or Basic Indicator Approach, ASA, or Alternative Standardized Approach, and ASA2, or Simplified Alternative Standardized Approach), with a single, more robust and risk-sensitive method, including an internal loss component that modulates the capital required. Res. 356 came into effect in January 2025. Nu Pagamentos&#8217;s prudential conglomerate uses ASA methodology for the RWAopad calculation, as approved by the Central Bank of Brazil on December 29, 2023. The aforementioned prudential conglomerate, led by Nu Pagamentos, comprises Nu Financeira, Nu Investimentos, NuPay and Nu Asset Management. Credit Risk Regulatory Framework Starting January 1st, 2025, Resolutions CMN No. 4.966 and BCB No. 352 came into effect. These regulations bring significant changes to the accounting of financial instruments in Brazil. These regulations aim to enhance alignment with international standards, particularly IFRS9, while accommodating jurisdiction-specific differences. Under the new regulatory framework, the methodology for calculating and accounting for expected credit loss (provisions) will be updated. &#160; On December 23, 2024, the Central Bank of Brazil issued Resolution No. 448, amending the BCB Resolution 199, to establish a transition schedule for incorporating the impacts of the new provisioning model into regulatory capital. This new provisioning model is based on CMN Resolution No. 4.966 and BCB resolution No. 352. The transition framework is aligned with the recommendations from the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (BCBS), allowing jurisdictions to phase in the regulatory capital impacts of increased provisions for expected credit loss over time. The rule partially restores regulatory capital that may have been reduced due to the shift to the new provisioning methodology. The transition period will span from 2025 to 2028. This adjustment aims to ensure that the metrics for risk exposure are managed sensitively . &#160; &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 95 &#160; &#160; Payment Institutions As per Central Bank of Brazil Resolution No. 80, of March 25, 2021, licensed payment institutions are required to comply with minimum paid-in capital per category in which they act. For institutions acting as issuers of post-paid payment instruments, issuers of electronic currency, or acquirers the minimum-paid in capital requirement is R$2.0 million per category of activity. For payment initiation service providers (PISP), the capital requirement is reduced to R$1.0 million. In addition, payment institutions that participate exclusively in closed payment schemes as issuers of electronic currency and issuers of post-paid payment instruments must comply with a minimum paid-in capital of R$3.0 million. Moreover, according to Central Bank of Brazil Resolutions No. 198, 199, 200, 201 and 202, all dated March 11, 2022, as well as Resolution No. 436, issued on November 28, 2024, a new set of rules was introduced to harmonize the prudential treatment applicable to payment services. The new prudential requirements are enforceable according to an implementation calendar, with full implementation beginning January 1, 2025. Under this framework, prudential conglomerates integrated by at least one institution that performs a payment service are now classified into one of the following types: &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Type 1: (i) single institution authorized to operate by the Central Bank of Brazil, except: payment institution; securities brokerage firms; securities distribution companies; and foreign exchange brokers; and (ii) prudential conglomerate led by an institution authorized to operate by the Central Bank of Brazil. &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Type 2: (i) single payment institution; and (ii) prudential conglomerate led by a payment institution and made up exclusively of: payment institutions authorized to operate by the Central Bank of Brazil; payment institutions not authorized to operate by the Central Bank of Brazil; entities that acquire credit operations, including real estate, or credit rights, such as commercial development companies, securitization companies and exclusive purpose companies; other legal entities whose exclusive corporate purpose is to hold shares in the entities mentioned in items i to iii; or investment funds; and &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Type 3: (i) securities brokers, securities distributors and foreign exchange brokerage firms; (b) prudential conglomerates led by the institutions referred above; and (c) prudential conglomerates led by a payment institution not mentioned in Type 2 above. According to the Central Bank of Brazil, the regulatory capital framework applicable to payment institutions was revised to enhance institutions&#180; capacity to absorb unexpected losses. This treatment will consist of deducting from the regulatory capital calculation the assets of the institution that, in situations of financial stress, have little or no value for maintaining the operation of the institution, in addition to considering debt instruments are now eligible for inclusion in Tier I and Tier II Regulatory Capital. Furthermore, these new rules seek to adjust the minimum capital requirement according to the intrinsic risks of each type of activity (payment or financial activity) for Type 3 prudential conglomerates (such as the one led by Nu Pagamentos). The framework acknowledges the peculiarities of payment services and their different legal status, and gives specific prudential treatment to the risks arising from them. In this context, the Payment Services Risk Weighted Assets, or &#8220;RWA SP ,&#8221; was created as a component for the calculation of regulatory capital in Type 1 and Type 3 prudential conglomerates, encompassing the activities of merchant acquiring, issuance of electronic currency, issuance of post-paid payment instruments and payment transaction initiation. &#160; &#160; Form 20-F | 2024 &#160; 96 &#160; &#160; Pursuant to BCB Resolutions No. 199 and 200, both dated March 11, 2022, or &#8220;BCB Resolution No.&#160;199/22&#8221; and &#8220;BCB Resolution No.&#160;200/22&#8221;, Brazil's capital requirement framework mandates that financial institutions maintain capital ratios based on their Total Capital relative to risk-weighted assets, or &#8220;RWAs&#8221;. Total Capital comprises Tier I Capital (formed by Common Equity and Additional Tier I Capital) and Tier II Capital. For purposes of calculating these minimum capital requirements, the total RWA is determined as the sum of the risk-weighted asset amounts for credit, market and operational risks. The Total Capital, used to monitor the compliance with the operational limits imposed by the Central Bank of Brazil, is the sum of three components: &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Common Equity Tier 1: includes social capital, reserves and retained earnings, less deductions and prudential adjustments. &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Additional Tier 1 Capital: comprises eligible perpetual instruments. When combined with Common Equity Tier I, it constitutes Tier I Capital. &#160; &#9679; &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Tier 2 Capital: consists of subordinated debt instruments with fixed maturity that meet certain eligibility requirements. Combined with Common Equity Tier I and Additional Tier I Capital, it makes up Total Capital. In accordance with applicable Brazilian regulations, we must maintain our Regulatory Capital, Tier 1 Capital and Common Equity Tier 1 Capital ratios above the minimum regulatory requirements thresholds established by the Central Bank of Brazil at all times. Beyond the minimum requirement, the Central Bank of Brazil mandates the inclusion of Additional Common Equity Tier I Capital, or &#8220;ACP,&#8221; comprising the sum of the ACP Conservation and ACP Countercyclical buffers, which, jointly with the requirements mentioned, increase capital requirements over time. With regard to prudential segmentation, this currently applies to Type 3 conglomerates such as ours. Under Brazil&#8217;s regulatory framework, Type 3 conglomerates are segmented from S2 to S5 based on size and complexity, with each segment subject to tailored prudential rules. As of the date of this annual report on Form 20-F, the Nu Pagamentos-led conglomerate is categorized in the S3 segment. However, we expect Nu Pagamentos to be classified as S2 within 2025. Internal teams are already working on all implementations needed, which involve preparation of new regulatory reports, new policies and procedures to be in place as well as new governance mechanisms.
